title: 107_hr2714
content: The "Date Certain Tax Code Replacement Act" sets a specific date for replacing the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 with a simpler and fairer alternative. The "Date Certain Tax Code Replacement Act" specifies the termination of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 after December 31, 2005, with exceptions for specific taxes. Additionally, it establishes a National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification. The Congress acknowledges that the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is overly complex, burdensome, and in need of fundamental reform and simplification. The current fiscal surplus provides a unique opportunity for tax law reform, as previous efforts have been unsuccessful. The National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification is established within the legislative branch to address the problems stemming from the complex tax code administered by the Internal Revenue Service. The Commission is composed of 15 members appointed by the President and the majority leader. The National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification is composed of 15 members appointed by the President and majority/minority leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives. The Commission elects a Chair from among its members and meets upon the call of the Chair. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the Chair or a majority of its members, with nine members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings may be held in executive session if deemed appropriate by the Chair or majority of members. If a member appointing individual leaves their position before the Commission's report is submitted, or if a member appointed to the Commission leaves, their membership may continue. The Commission members can continue for up to 30 days after leaving their position or becoming a government officer or employee. It is recommended that members be appointed within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The Commission, established by the Act, can begin operations after 60 days if eight or more members are appointed. The Commission's functions include conducting a review for up to 18 months and submitting a report to Congress with recommendations. The Commission will conduct a review of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, focusing on its impact on the economy, families, compliance costs, and taxpayer burden. Recommendations for fundamental reform and simplification will be included in the report to Congress. The Commission will review the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, considering the IRS's ability to administer it, exploring more efficient tax systems from other countries, discussing the possibility of replacing income tax with a different tax, and evaluating if the Code can be simplified without complete restructuring. The Commission has the power to authorize subcommittees or members to carry out its provisions. The Commission, in carrying out its provisions, may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and administer oaths as deemed advisable. It can also enter into contracts and secure assistance from federal agencies and offices for information. The Commission can request information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics from various government entities for its review and report. The Treasury Department can provide administrative services and support to the Commission. The Commission can request administrative support services, legal analysis, and other assistance from various government entities for its functions. The General Services Administration and Joint Committee on Taxation are authorized to provide nonreimbursable support to the Commission. The Commission is authorized to receive support services, funds, facilities, staff, and other assistance from US departments and agencies. It can also utilize postal services and accept gifts or donations. The Chair can appoint a staff director and set their compensation. The Commission can appoint a staff director and other necessary personnel without following certain regulations on appointments and pay rates. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission can appoint staff and consultants at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. Members may be compensated at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Members of the Commission are compensated at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing services for the Commission. Officers or employees of the United States or Members of Congress serving on the Commission do not receive additional pay. The Commission must submit a report to the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee within 18 months of its first meeting. The report should detail the results of its review, recommend reforms to the tax code, and assess the economic impact of these recommendations. The Commission will terminate once its duties are fulfilled. The Commission's activities will end 90 days after the report is due. They can use this time to conclude their work, testify to Congress, and share the report. Funds are authorized for the Commission's activities, with $2,000,000 available from the Treasury Department until specific appropriations are made. The Congress declares that any new Federal tax system must be approved by July 4, 2005, to avoid reauthorization of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
